Outward and visible signs

Institute for Church Life

The University of Notre Dame

Helping tell stories about the complex realities of contemporary Church life.

Read a 0-minute case study

Each year, thousands of banks and other financial institutions report data about mortgages to the public as part of the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act, or “Hum-Dah," for short. HMDA data is a view of the mortgage market, an important part of the American economy. But with over 18.7 million records reported by 7,400 financial institutions in 2012 alone, the data can be difficult to use. As a user experience designer with the CFPB, I worked to modernize this data into a useful tool for both experts and the curious.

Context

This project was a joint effort between two areas of the Bureau. A team of mortgage lending industry experts needed to publish a large amount of data as mandated by the Dodd-Frank Act. Members of the Technology and Innovation team were building a new platform to increase public access to open data. The project was an opportunity to increase government transparency, a major goal of the Bureau. Success for the project would be the delivery of a product that gave users accurate data.

1.

With two product owners representing different industries, participatory design exercises were essential for collaboration during the discovery phase of the project. In many ways, this phase of the project resembled a crash course in statistics for designers. But without it, the team would be unable to deliver a usable, accurate product, and any empathy on our part would be mere sympathy.

The first needfinding session would reveal that traditional personas would be insufficient for this project. The potential audiences we identified as a team were too many; their roles, workflows, and quirks, too disparate.

Different audience prioritizations favored one product owner over another. For a product with a highly-techical existing audience, it was important to make stakeholders feel that audience heard.

The win depended on detaching UX success away from a deliverable and focusing instead on how to guide a conversation. I took a step back in my process and found that I was mapping potential audiences across two themes: technical expertise and subject matter expertise. I reframed needfinding artifacts into user story hooks, definitions of success, and biggest risks. Bringing a visual representation of different types of people and their work to the table (no pun inteded) facilitated relative, not ad-hoc, prioritization.

At this point, I didn't even have to deliver a pitch anymore; as a designer, I didn't see these groupings of people as technical or not; subject matter experts or not. Rather, I saw people who wanted to hear stories and those wanted to tell them; people who had questions and those that could answer them. The difference for communicating this one way over the other was, well, based on audience.

With creative problem solving and faith in the rewards of participatory design, I focused on the goals of UX instead of the deliverables associated with it. I was able to pitch a project vision to two product owners in a way that made them both feel heard, and that everyone on the team could get behind.

2.

User research showed that workflow would be hard to change. HMDA data has been a certain way for many years and the research industry is slow to change. Research and peer-review requires consistency in order to enhance collaboration and peer-review. We couldn’t come up with new “data that was interesting to *us*” the designers. they had years of concentrated expertise in this. plus, it’s a legal thing. we needed to listen.

Interaction Design

3.

The HMDA UI incorporates research-based design choices that lessen cognitive overload, encouraging selective attention, and communicate abstract information using familiar syntax and plain language.

Usability testing

4.

We tested HMDA Explore at various stages of development with our expert and non-expert audiences to figure out where our pain points were. Experts included economists within the Bureau whose work involves fair lending practices;

non-experts included policy workers from advocacy groups in DC whose work involves certain demographics. Our first goal was to assess whether Explore was a swift tool for experts, who would be familiar with much of the terminology used in the UI. Second, we wanted to assess whether our plain language efforts correctly guided non-experts through the tool.

Github played a major role in how we iterated based on the feedback we got in these sessions. We documented our feedback in a wiki, and created issues for each part of the UI that needed to change. Github allowed the entire team to join the conversation and follow UX's process.

Iteration

The HMDA UI incorporates research-based design choices that lessen cognitive overload, encouraging selective attention, and communicate abstract information using familiar syntax and plain language.
